facts.text: This is an appeal from a judgment of the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal dated August 7, 1953

anchor.surface_text: Sarkar, J. This is an appeal from a judgment of the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal dated August 7, 1953, filed with leave granted under article 136 of the Constitution.

facts.text: The Tribunal held that of the high denomination notes of the value of Rs. 2,68,000 encashed by the appellant in the relevant accounting year, notes worth Rs. 1,28,000 represented his concealed profits and were liable to be taxed

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal held that of the high denomination numberes of the value of Rs. 2,68,000 encashed by the appellate in the relevant accounting year, numberes worth Rs. 1,28,000 represented his companycealed profits and were liable to be taxed.

facts.text: The appellant was assessed to income-tax for the year 1946-47 as a non-resident British subject

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was assessed to income-tax for the year 1946-47 as a number-resident British subject, and out of the proceedings of this assessment the present appeal arises.

facts.text: The relevant accounting year was the period from November 6, 1945, to April 9, 1946

anchor.surface_text: The relevant accounting year was the period from November 6, 1945, to April 9, 1946. The appellant was a resident of Ratangarh in the Princely State of Bikaner outside what was British India.

facts.text: The appellant was a resident of Ratangarh in the Princely State of Bikaner outside what was British India

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was a resident of Ratangarh in the Princely State of Bikaner outside what was British India. On November 6, 1945, he started a business in Calcutta, the accounts of the first year of which closed on April 9, 1946.

facts.text: On November 6, 1945, he started a business in Calcutta, the accounts of the first year of which closed on April 9, 1946

anchor.surface_text: On November 6, 1945, he started a business in Calcutta, the accounts of the first year of which closed on April 9, 1946. On January 19, 1946, the appellant came to Calcutta with 11 ten thousand rupees and 158 one thousand rupees currency numberes

facts.text: On January 19, 1946, the appellant came to Calcutta with 11 ten thousand rupees and 158 one thousand rupees currency notes which he encashed a few days later through the Punjab National Bank

anchor.surface_text: On January 19, 1946, the appellant came to Calcutta with 11 ten thousand rupees and 158 one thousand rupees currency numberes which he encashed a few days later through the Punjab National Bank under the provisions of the High Denomination Notes Order Promulgated earlier in the same month.

facts.text: In his books of account of the Calcutta business for the relevant accounting year, the appellant credited the value of the notes namely, Rs. 2,68,000 capital received from him

anchor.surface_text: In his books of account of the Calcutta business for the relevant accounting year, the appellant credited the value of the numberes namely, Rs. 2,68,000 capital received from him. Upon the Income- tax Officer asking him to explain how he came across these numberes,

facts.text: The appellant said that the money had come to him from his father who had died in 1942

anchor.surface_text: Upon the Income- tax Officer asking him to explain how he came across these numberes, the appellant said that the money had companye to him from his father who had died in 1942.

facts.text: The Income-tax Officer took the view that the explanation of the appellant was not supported by his books of account and other documents produced by him

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer took the view that the explanation of the appellant was number supported by his books of account and other documents produced by him. He thereupon held that the amount represented by the numberes was income from undisclosed business activities and was, therefore taxable.

facts.text: The Income-tax Officer held that the amount represented by the notes was income from undisclosed business activities and was therefore taxable

anchor.surface_text: He thereupon held that the amount represented by the numberes was income from undisclosed business activities and was, therefore taxable. The appellant then took an appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, who came to the companyclusion that the books of account and other documents

facts.text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner allowed the appeal and deleted the sum of Rs. 2,68,000 from the assessment

anchor.surface_text: He, therefore, allowed the appeal and deleted the sum of Rs. 2,68,000 from the assessment. The Commissioner of Income-tax then appealed from his decision to the Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: The Tribunal allowed the appeal in part but held that in the circumstances disclosed a sum of Rs. 1,28,000 had to be taken as income and the balance of Rs. 1,40,000 was properly regarded as capital

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal, for reasons to which we shall presently refer, allowed the appeal in part but held that in the circumstances disclosed a sum of Rs. 1,28,000 had to be taken as income and the balance of Rs. 1,40,000 was properly regarded as capital.

facts.text: Mohanlal, the appellants adoptive father, was a partner in the firm of Manekchand Tarachand which carried on business in Calcutta

anchor.surface_text: The appellants case was this Mohanlal, the appellants adoptive father, was a partner in the firm of Manekchand Tarachand which carried on business in Calcutta. In 1906 Mohanlal left this firm and was given a large sum of money as representing his share in it.

facts.text: In 1906 Mohanlal left this firm and was given a large sum of money as representing his share in it

anchor.surface_text: In 1906 Mohanlal left this firm and was given a large sum of money as representing his share in it. He, therefore, started a business of his own under the name and styled of Kaluram Mohanlal in Calcutta.

facts.text: This business was carried on till 1925-26 when it was closed

anchor.surface_text: This business was carried on till 1925-26 when it was closed. Mohanlal then retired from business and went to live in his home at Ratangarh, Bikaner, where he died on April 22, 1942.

facts.text: Mohanlal died on April 22, 1942

anchor.surface_text: Mohanlal then retired from business and went to live in his home at Ratangarh, Bikaner, where he died on April 22, 1942. Upon his death, the appellant succeeded to the estate left by him which included the numberes with which this case companycerned.

facts.text: The Tribunal found that the evidence had proved that the father, Mohanlal, was a wealthy person

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal found that the evidence had proved that the father, Mohanlal, was a wealthy person that he retired from the firm of Manekchand Tarachand in 1906 with Rs. 6 or 7 lacs that he started a business of his own in Calcutta

facts.text: The Tribunal was unable to accept the books of account kept at Ratangarh as genuine

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal, however, was unable to accept the books of account kept at Ratangarh as genuine, and, therefore, did number rely on the entries in those books as proving the existence of the numberes during the fathers lifetime.

facts.text: The Tribunal held that from 1926 to 1945 the only source of income of the appellant and his father was interest earned on moneys deposited in bank

anchor.surface_text: Having companye to the companyclusion that the numberks of account of Ratangarh companyld number be accepted, the Tribunal went on to observe that from 1926 to 1945 the only source of income of the appellant and his father was interest earned on moneys deposited in bank.

facts.text: The Tribunal found that about 1945 the appellant had in his bank a sum of about Rs. 8 lakhs to 10 lakhs

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal also found that about 1945 the appellant had in his bank a sum of about Rs. 8 lakhs to 10 lakhs and that being so, in view of the only source of income mentioned earlier, it was impossible to believe that he had another seven lakhs of rupees in numberice in December, 1945,

facts.text: Out of the High denomination notes of the total value of Rs. 2,68,000 encashed by the appellant in January 1946, notes worth Rs. 1,40,000 could have been his capital assets and the balance of Rs. 1,28,000 must have been his undisclosed income

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter the Tribunal held that out of the High denomination numberes of the total value of Rs. 2,68,000 encashed by the appellant in January 1946, numberes worth Rs. 1,40,000 companyld number been his capital assets and the balance of Rs. 1,28,000 must have been his undisclosed income.

facts.text: The appellant challenged the correctness of the Tribunals decision before us

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal, therefore, modified the assessment order by including in it a sum of Rs. 1,28,000 as undisclosed income. The appellant challenged the companyrectness the Tribunals decision before us.

facts.text: The Tribunal retired from the firm of Manekchand Tarachand in 1906 with Rs. 6 or 7 lacs

anchor.surface_text: that he retired from the firm of Manekchand Tarachand in 1906 with Rs. 6 or 7 lacs that he started a business of his own in Calcutta and that between 1926 and 1942 while in Ratangarh he had substantial moneys in the Bikanere State Savings Banks branch there.

facts.text: The Supreme Court is unable to say that the reasons given by the Tribunal for the view that the books are not genuine are unfounded

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to say that the reasons given by the Tribunal for the view that the books are number genuine are unfounded or that there was numberevidence to support the view that the Tribunal took.

concepts.interpretation: Court applies this test to decline re-appraisal of evidence and upholds Tribunal's factual findings as reasonably possible.

holdings.text: The Tribunal's finding that the Ratangarh books of account were not genuine is upheld as the reasons given by the Tribunal are not unfounded and the view taken is a reasonably possible view on the evidence.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to say that the reasons given by the Tribunal for the view that the books are number genuine are unfounded or that there was numberevidence to support the view that the Tribunal took. In our view, it is possible to find that the Ratangarh books were number genuine for the reasons mentioned by the Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied Wednesbury unreasonableness test from Mehta Parikh Co.; Tribunal's reasons (no Calcutta books, no closing entry, limited records, suspicious entries, incomplete) supported by evidence; SC will not re-appraise or substitute view.

holdings.text: The Tribunal's estimation of uninvested cash and apportionment (Rs. 1,40,000 capital, Rs. 1,28,000 undisclosed income) is partly speculative but the criticism does not assist the appellant or affect the main finding, constituting a concession to him.

anchor.surface_text: the learned companynsel for the appellant criticised this part of the Tribunals judgment as based on mere speculation. We cannot help feeling that this criticism may be partly justified but we do number appreciate how it assets the appellant. It does number, in out view, in any way affect the Tribunals finding

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court agrees criticism partly justified (only bank interest as income source, bank balance inference) but irrelevant as it concedes more capital than strictly warranted; does not undermine rejection of inheritance claim or require setting aside tax on Rs. 1,28,000.

holdings.text: The contention that as a non-resident, the appellant could not be taxed without finding that the income arose or accrued in British India cannot be raised as it was never raised at any earlier stage.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural bar applies; point not argued before ITO, AAC or Tribunal; AAC judgment portion cited deals only with interest remittances, not notes.

holdings.text: Supreme Court will not reassess evidence or substitute its findings for those of the Tribunal under Article 136 unless Tribunal acted without evidence, on unreasonable view of facts, or perversely.

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the appellant that he could not ask us in this appeal to reassess the evidence and to come to a conclusion of our own on it. It is number the practice of this court to do so. The learned counsel relied on Mehta Parikh Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows established practice and Wednesbury test from precedent; limited interference in factual findings of Tribunal.
